segments.text: Houston, this is ISS. We've got a problem with the water recycling system. I'm seeing a pressure drop in the primary loop.
Copy that, ISS. Can you give us the exact reading? What's the current pressure?
Nominal should be 18 PSI. I'm reading 14.2 and falling slowly. Rate of drop is about 0.3 PSI per hour.
Understood. That's not critical yet, but we need to identify the leak. Can you check the connections at panel R7?
Roger. Moving to panel R7 now. Dr. Novak, can you pull up the system schematic on your tablet?
On it. Schematic loading. Okay, panel R7 has six connection points. The most likely culprits are joints three and five.
Opening panel R7. Visual inspection first. I'm looking for moisture, condensation, anything unusual.
Joints one and two look dry. Joint three... wait, I see some wetness around the coupling. Houston, I think we found it.
Good work, Chen. Is it a seal failure or a loose connection?
Let me check the torque. Getting my wrench. Trying to tighten joint three... it's turning. Definitely was loose.
That joint gets a lot of thermal cycling. The temperature variations can cause fittings to loosen over time.
Makes sense. Tightening now... quarter turn... half turn... feeling resistance. There, it's snug. Torque feels right.
Chen, wipe down the area and wait five minutes. We need to confirm the leak has stopped.
Copy that. Using a clean rag to dry the joint completely. It'll be obvious if new moisture appears.
While we wait, want me to check the other joints? Preventive inspection?
Good idea. Let's make sure the others are secure. Check joints four, five, and six while I monitor the pressure gauge.
Joint four looks good, tight and dry. Joint five is also secure. Joint six... this one could use a small adjustment.
Go ahead and snug it up. Better to prevent future problems now.
Tightening joint six. There, that's better. All connections now feel uniform.
ISS, how's the pressure reading now?
Houston, pressure is holding at 14.2. No further drop in the last... let me check the timestamp... four minutes.
Excellent. Check joint three for new moisture.
Inspecting joint three now. It's completely dry. No new condensation. The leak appears to be sealed.
Outstanding work. We'll continue monitoring remotely. Can you manually repressurize the system back to 18 PSI?
Affirmative. Accessing the pressurization controls. Opening the makeup water valve to restore system pressure.
Pressure rising. 14.5... 15.0... 15.5... looking good.
16.0... 16.5... 17.0... approaching target. 17.5... 18.0 PSI. Closing the makeup valve now.
Perfect. We're seeing the same readings on our telemetry. System looks stable.
Confirmed. Pressure holding at 18 PSI. All indicators green. Water recycling system is back to nominal operation.
That was some good troubleshooting. Quick identification, clean fix.
Teamwork. Houston's guidance, your schematic support, my wrench. That's how we solve problems up here.
We'll note this in the maintenance log. Recommend inspecting those joints every two weeks going forward.
Agreed. I'll add it to the recurring maintenance schedule. Dr. Novak and I will do a joint inspection every other Monday.
Works for me. Better to catch these issues early than deal with a major system failure.
Houston, closing panel R7. Is there anything else you need from us on this issue?
Negative, Chen. You're cleared to proceed with your scheduled activities. Nice work up there.
Thank you, Houston. Panel secured. Returning to normal operations. ISS out.

environment.background_sounds: equipment humming, tool sounds, communication static, water system sounds
